awd_titl_txt: SG: Demographic drivers of plant community response to fire: Re-evaluating the relative importance of survival vs. reproduction
awd_abstract_narration:
Before European-American settlement in the 1800s, the vast grasslands of North America burned every 2-5 years. These frequent fires maintained grassland habitat and contributed to the diversity of birds, mammals, insects, and plants found in prairies today. Widespread habitat loss and the elimination of fire are causing native plant populations to decline in the few prairie patches that remain. The loss of native plant diversity has motivated many Americans to take action. People, businesses, and agencies of local, state, and the federal government conduct prescribed burns to improve habitat and promote prairie plant diversity. Understanding why native prairie plants thrive with fire is essential for achieving these management goals. In addition to sharing results that will advance the fundamental scientific knowledge about fires and plant populations, the researchers will share practical information with land managers, conservation practitioners, policy-makers, and the public to help them make better decisions about how frequently to burn prairies to achieve their management goals. In addition to disseminating scientific results and recommendations, this project will provide research experience and training to a postdoctoral researcher and two college students, as well as opportunities for engagement by high-school students, secondary-school science teachers, and conservation research volunteers in Minnesota and at the Chicago Botanic Garden.

This research project will investigate how fire maintains healthy populations of native perennial plants in western Minnesota. Scientists have two main hypotheses about fire: on one hand, fires may help native plants compete and survive; on the other hand, fires may help plants flower, get pollinated, and produce seeds. Evidence exists for both hypotheses and both survival and reproduction are necessary to maintain a population, but how much fire influences each process remains an open scientific question. The researchers will test the hypothesis that the reproductive benefits of synchronized flowering after fire help promote population growth and forestall local extinctions. They will randomly assign burn treatments in 30 prairies, where they will 1) examine the effects of fire on pollination and reproduction in previously-studied populations of a purple coneflower, Echinacea angustifolia, 2) conduct a seed addition experiment to characterize the influence of fire on seed germination and seedling survival, 3) develop models to quantify effects of fire on Echinacea population growth, and 4) estimate fire effects on mating and reproduction in three other widespread prairie species.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project builds on a long-term demographic study to evaluate how habitat fragmentation and fire influence plant populations within remnants of tallgrass prairie in Minnesota. At the beginning of the 1800s, tallgrass prairie stretched over 167 million acres of North America. Habitat destruction has since reduced prairie to a small fraction of its historic extent. In Minnesota, less than 1 percent of the original 18 million acres of prairie remains. Most remnants of prairie habitat are small, isolated, and experiencing high rates of local plant extinction. Periodic fires help maintain native plant diversity in this historically fire-dependent habitat but our understanding of the demographic processes underlying the beneficial effects of fire remains limited. The leading hypothesis is that fire modifies the physical environment in ways that improve plant survival; for example, fire removes litter which increases light and promotes survival. However, we hypothesize that fire synchronizes flowering and improves pollination, which promotes population growth and persistence.

During the term of this award (2020-2023), we experimentally evaluated how fire influences the reproduction and demography of five plant species within fragmented prairie remnants in western Minesota. We have shared our findings with other scientists, land stewards, managers, practitioners, and policymakers through publications in scientific journals, at scientific meetings, and in workshops. Among our key results (details are presented in published articles, posted on our website, echinaceaproject.org):

1. Fire enhanced mating opportunities and seed production in large populations, but fire did not consistently benefit seed production in small populations with fewer than 30 individuals. This finding reveals how habitat fragmentation can constrain the reproductive benefits of fire in plant populations. We learned this by experimentally burning natural populations of Echinacea angustifolia ranging in size from 3 to more than 4000 individual plants. Prescribed fire consistently increased reproductive effort (flowering) across the full range of population sizes but not reproductive outcomes (seed production).

2. We established an experiment to test the hypothesis that fire promotes seedling establishment by increasing light and reducing competition. We experimentally sowed ~12,000 Echinacea seeds across 36 remnant prairies over two seasons to evaluate how prescribed fire influences rates of seedling emergence and survival. We assessed light and competition each year. This experiment is ongoing.

3. Using long-term demographic information from more than 6000 individual Echinacea plants across 35 natural populations, we began developing demographic models to assess how fire influences rates of population growth in populations ranging from 3 to more than 4000 plants. Additionally, these demographic models will enable us to test competing hypotheses about the mechanism by which fire promotes population growth. Specifically, we laid the foundation to assess the relative importance of seedling emergence and survival vs. seed production in determining population growth rates.

4. We examined reproductive responses to fire in four additional species to evaluate whether our findings for E. angustifolia extend to other species. We found fire increases reproductive effort in Andropogon gerardii -- a widespread and ecologically dominant grass, Liatris aspera -- a common plant and close relative of Echinacea, and Ascelpias viridiflora -- an uncommon species that occurs at low population densities. Rates of seed production decline with distance to prospective mates in both Liatris aspera and Lilium philadelphicum -- another uncommon prairie plant species. These findings highlight the similar processes that influence plant reproductive responses in many plant species.

5. We developed and published a comparative literature review that revealed many parallels between the fields of masting and fire-stimulated flowering but little dialogue between fields. Using long-term data on E. angustifolia reproduction, we showed that fire-stimulated flowering generates interannual reproductive variation that is strikingly similar to that observed in masting species. We compiled a database of 1870 species to facilitate comparative review of these fields and their complementary insights. This contribution lays the foundation for a synthesis that has potential to greatly advance our understanding of the causes and consequences of sychronized reproductive variation in perennial plants.

During the award, we mentored scientists, educators, and a postdoctoral researcher. We also involved many graduate, undergraduate, and high school students, high-school biology teachers, college professors, and many volunteers in our research efforts. These individuals gained hands-on experience conducting scientific research and helped advance understanding of fire’s influence on plant demography in fragmented ecosystems.

We maintain a website (http://echinaceaproject.org/) that helps disseminate results, organize datasets, and curate collections. The website provides information on how to improve the conservation and management of perennial populations in fragmented habitat. In addition, the website furthers our educational goals with links to educational materials and postings about internship and employment opportunities. We keep project members, collaborators, and the public informed about our scientific activities with a blog.

Please visit our website for current information on our activities and learn about our latest exciting findings!
